A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. 6 To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Gluck: Tony Stewart retiring from Sprint Cup racing on his terms Jeff Gluck , USA TODAY Sports 6:50 p.m. EDT September 30, 2015 Three-time NASCAR champion Tony Stewart announces he will retire after the 2016 season during a news conference Wednesday. (Photo: Chuck Burton, AP) 213 CONNECT 76 TWEET LINKEDIN 6 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
KANNAPOLIS, N.C. — Tony Stewart grinned, winked, cracked wise and showed flashes of his old self during a 53-minute news conference Wednesday. 
It's a good thing Stewart's retirement announcement isn't effective until after 2016. The man they call Smoke might be getting back to his true personality just in time to give himself and his fans one more fun year. 
If there’s anything to take from his answers and attitude Wednesday, when Stewart said Clint Bowyer will replace him in the No. 14 car beginning in 2017, it’s that Stewart suddenly looks happier than he’s been in the last few seasons. Appeals panel upholds penalties against Clint Bowyer and MWR 
He jokingly appointed himself as the second driver for co-owner Gene Haas’ new Formula One team , announced he was naming 75-year-old Harry Gant to take his seat and theorized he might go “sightseeing” in the rowdy infields of some tracks after he quits driving. 
The decision, he made it clear, was his decision on his terms. It had “zero percent” to do with the badly broken leg he suffered in 2013 or the tragedy that killed Kevin Ward Jr. last year . It also didn’t have anything to do with his lackluster results lately, he said. <!--iframe--> 
“It's the right thing,” he said. “It's not performance‑based, it's just time to do what we're doing. I still fully anticipate we're going to get things turned around. If I didn't feel that way, I wouldn't waste my time next year for anybody.” 
And next year, Stewart hinted, could be a vintage one for perhaps the greatest driver of his generation. He vowed to be a thorn in NASCAR’s side like he used to be, in preparation for getting called to the hauler once he’s just a team owner instead of an owner/driver. NASCAR will lose star power when Tony Stewart walks away 
He issued a not-so-subtle warning to his competitors, too, emphasizing he’ll race like he has nothing to lose. 
“Next year is not a coast-and-collect year,” he said. “It's just the opposite because I don't have to worry about making anybody mad next year and having to deal with it in 2017. I can rough everybody up next year if that's what it takes to accomplish my goals and sit there and just smile and laugh about it at Homestead.” 
Even after he finally stops driving in the Cup Series, he said, “I'm still going to be at the track harassing everybody, so nobody is getting a free pass now.” 
The return of the prankster, sarcastic Stewart would be a welcome sight, although it also might be a case of “Be careful what you wish for.” But that's because Stewart has seemed increasingly miserable since the pinnacle of his career in 2011, when he won his third championship on a tiebreaker in one of NASCAR’s all-time performances. 
His results were already slipping before a sprint car crash shattered his leg in 2013, and it wasn’t getting any better in 2014 before the Ward accident. In public appearances, the spark has gone out of his eye. 
It's been painful to watch his swagger disappear, his confidence dwindle, his results tank. Stewart just wasn't the same driver he used to be. 
That could be changing soon, though. Last year, sitting on the same stage in the Haas F1 Team’s auditorium, Stewart said the thought of retiring would “take the life out of me.” 
But Wednesday, he emphasized he isn’t retiring from driving — just from the Sprint Cup Series. There are other races to be run, and on his schedule instead of NASCAR’s. 
Stewart spoke of racing a truck at the Eldora Speedway dirt track he owns in Ohio, getting into a modified car at New Hampshire Motor Speedway and even “maybe, probably” returning to sprint car races. 
Plus, he’ll still be around NASCAR as a co-owner at Stewart-Haas Racing. 
“I'm not leaving the sport I love,” he said. “I'm not walking away from something I'm passionate about — I'm just changing roles, which is like just moving to a different position in a company.” 
In the meantime, he has one more chance at the big races which have eluded him — the Daytona 500 and Darlington's Southern 500 — and perhaps the opportunity to get a fourth championship next season. He warned reporters to write down his 2016 goals now instead of asking him about it next year, because, in typical Stewart fashion, he likely won’t have the patience for those questions after Wednesday. NASCAR drivers, fans react to Tony Stewart's retirement announcment 
The 44-year-old vowed to avoid the weekly media center trips like the ones Jeff Gordon has been taking this year to discuss his career and receive retirement gifts from track presidents. A retirement tour like that one, Stewart said, wasn't his style. 
“You can save your gifts,” he said. “… I'm not really that kind of guy. I'm content to go race and be around the racing community and the racing family and be around our fans. They can just send me a note from the track president and say, ‘Hey, thank you,’ and that'll be sufficient for me.” 
But the main reason Stewart even decided to race one more year was to acknowledge the fans. Otherwise, he might have preferred to clap his hands like a blackjack dealer at the end of his shift, then “turn around and walk out of the building,” he said. 
“The reason that we decided to go ahead and run through the end of next year is 100% because of the fans that have supported us through the years,” he said. “It's as important for me to do this for them as it is for me to do what I'm doing for my future.” 
And that future suddenly looks a lot happier for a man who hadn't seemed very happy until Wednesday.

Tony Stewart, born May 20, 1971, in Columbus, Ind., is a three time NASCAR Cup Series champion (2002, '05, 11), the 1997 Indy Racing League (IndyCar) champion and the 1995 USAC Triple Crown champion. Andrew Weber, USA TODAY Sports Tony Stewart during driver introductions prior to the 2015 Pure Michigan 400 at Michigan International Speedway. Andrew Weber, USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Kevin Ward Jr. was struck and killed by a car driven by Tony Stewart during an Empire Super Sprints race at Canandaigua (N.Y.) Motorsports Park on August 9, 2014. On Sept. 24, 2014, the Grand Jury completed its investigation and announced no criminal charges would be filed against Stewart. Cheryl Senter, AP Tony Stewart signs autographs for fans during practice for the 2014 Coke Zero 400 at Daytona International Speedway. Jasen Vinlove, USA TODAY Sports Tony Stewart poses with a Texas Motor Speedway rifle after winning the pole for the 2014 Duck Commander 500 in Fort Worth. Jerome Miron, USA TODAY Sports Tony Stewart told reporters at a Sept. 3 newsconference, "I've damn near passed out at every doctor visit I've been to so far," because there was so much skin damage. Jeff Gluck, USA TODAY Sports Tony Stewart gets wheeled into a press conference on Sept. 3. Stewart fractured his tibia and fibula in a sprint car crash in Iowa on Aug. 5, 2013. Chuck Burton, AP Tony Stewart, not visible, is checked over by medics after being involved in a four-car wreck at Southern Iowa Speedway in Oskaloosa. Mary Willie, Des Moines Register Mark Martin, left, talks to Tony Stewart during the drivers' introductory lap before the Sprint Cup race in Fontana, Calif., in 2013. Reed Saxon, AP Tony Stewart, above, stars in a Mobil 1 commercial with Formula One driver Jenson Button. Ed Szczepanski, USA TODAY Sports Jeff Burton, left, says he's come to like and respect Tony Stewart, right, quite a bit over the years. Jerome Miron, USA TODAY Sports Three-time Sprint Cup champion Tony Stewart plans to drive over 100 races at smaller venues this season. True Speed Communications Stewart Haas Racing expanded to three cars in 2013, adding Danica Patrick as a full-time driver in Sprint Cup. Mark J. Rebilas, USA TODAY Sports Stewart endures yet another photo shoot, this one in his Nationwide Series suit. "Nice, nice!" shouts a director. "You're a pro. That was bad ass." Nate Ryan, USA TODAY Sports The team owner says of balancing the demands on his time: "I've got more stuff asked of me every week. But I drive a race car for a living. … Life's good." Nate Ryan, USA TODAY Sports Stewart throws his helmet at Matt Kenseth's car after the two collided racing for the lead on lap 333 during the 2012 Irwin Tools Night Race in Bristol, Tenn. Earl Neikirk, AP Tony Stewart celebrates winning the 2011 Coke Zero 400 at Daytona International Speedway. Kevin Liles, USA TODAY Sports Stewart drives the No. 14 Chevrolet during the Feed the Children Prelude to the Dream at Eldora Speedway on June 6, 2012 in Rossburg, Ohio. Stewart bought Eldora Speedway in 2004. Chris Graythen, Getty Images President Barack Obama (right) talks with NASCAR Sprint Cup Series champion Tony Stewart during an event to honor him and the other 2011 Sprint Cup Series drivers at the White House on Tuesday, April 17, 2012. Evan Vucci, AP Danica Patrick (left) talks with Stewart during practice for the 2012 Daytona 500. 2012 was Patrick's first season as a driver for Stewart's team, Stewart-Haas Racing, Tom Pennington, Getty Images Stewart and his crew push his midget car to the track before he competes in the 2012 Race of Champions at the Chili Bowl Midget Nationals in Tulsa, Okla. Michael Wyke, AP Fullscreen Stewart, driver of the No. 14 Office Depot/Mobil 1 Chevrolet, celebrates in after winning the NASCAR Sprint Cup Series Ford 400 and the 2011 Series Championship at Homestead-Miami Speedway on November 20, 2011 in Homestead, Florida. The title was Stewart's third Cup series championship, having previously won in 2002 and 2005. Jared C. Tilton, Getty Images Stewart celebrates his third Sprint Cup title with his mother Pam Boas at Homestead-Miami Speedway in November 2011. Mark J. Rebilas, USA TODAY Sports There always is a media crush around the three-time Sprint Cup champion, shown here at Daytona Speedweeks in 2010. Andrew P. Scott, USA TODAY Sports After driving for Joe Gibbs Racing for 10 years, Stewart became a team owner and driver with Stewart Hass Racing in 2009. Davis Turner for USA TODAY Sports Stewart, an Indiana native, kisses the bricks after winning the 14th running of the Allstate 400 at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway in July of 2007. Sam Riche, Indianapolis Star Stewart shows his frustration after a last lap crash during the 2007 Aaron's 499 at Talladega Superspeedway. Marvin Gentry, USA TODAY Sports Tony Stewart, left, shown with Ryan Newman in November 2005. Stewart would later become Newman's boss when he ran his own team. Matt Slocum, AP Stewart celebrates his first Brickyard win by climbing the fence at the finish line with his team on Aug. 7, 2005. Sam Riche, Indianapolis Star Stewart (right) celebrates atop the flag stand near fans at Daytona International Speedway after winning the 2005 Pepsi 400. According to National Motorsports Press Association (NMPA), Stewart is one of the Top 10 most popular drivers in NASCAR. David Graham, AP Stewart won the Pepsi 400 at Daytona International Speedway in July 2005 for the first of four wins in the summer race there. David Graham, AP Stewart and Dale Earnhardt Jr. talk after the first session of practice for the Bud Shootout in 2004. Tim Dillon, USA TODAY Sports Stewart signs a car for Philip Simons in May 2003. Eileen Blass, USA TODAY Sports Stewart drives through the first turn at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway during the final practice session before the 85th running of the Indianapolis 500 in 2001. Stewart occasionally raced in the IZOD IndyCar series from 1996-2001. Michael Conroy, AP Tony Stewart (20) flies through the air after an accident during the 2001 Daytona 500. Despite winning three Cup championships and racking up 47 career wins, Stewart has yet to win a Daytona 500. Jim Topper, AP Stewart (20) passes Jeff Gordon (24) en route to winning his first Winston Cup Series race at the Richmond International Raceway in Richmond, Va., Saturday, Sept. 11, 1999.
